prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Summarized Context:

Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 2
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 3
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A scholar sent to Britain by the Japanese government to further his study of English. He's the defendant accused of attempted murder.
Character 4
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 5
Name: Maid → Joan Garrideb
Description: A maid who works at the Garrideb household. Her main duty appears to be standing at Mr Garrideb's side pouring tea.
Character 6
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 7
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous 'great detective'. Not a person except me, apparently.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey, though concrete details of the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Olive Green
Description: The victim of this case, who was found with a knife in her back. Luckily, the wound didn't prove fatal, but the woman remains unconscious in her hospital bed.
Character 10
Name: Roly Beate
Description: A devoted London bobby who witnessed the incident whilst walking down the street with his wife of a year, Patricia.
Character 11
Name: Patricia Beate
Description: The wife of Constable Roly Beate who is a witness to the incident. She's relatively recently married, and fiercely proud of her policeman husband.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Local Map
Description: A street map of the local area showing where the victim was found. A street map of the local area showing locations that are relevant to the case.
Evidence 2
Name: Iris's Postcard
Description: A card for Inspector Gregson with a message on the back from Iris.
Evidence 3
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt discovered in Mr Natsume's room for some books that he had purchased from a secondhand bookshop before the incident occurred.
Evidence 4
Name: Case File
Description: A file containing an overview of the case and details about the victim. She was found with a knife in her back and is currently in hospital, yet to regain consciousness. The pavement where the victim was found lies just outside Constable Beate's beat, the border of which runs down the middle of Briar Road.
Evidence 5
Name: Jackknife
Description: A large but commonplace folding knife. It was found lodged in the victim's back.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident occurred. A large knife can be seen thrust into the victim's back.
Evidence 7
Name: Crime Scene Photograph #2
Description: A second photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident. It specifically shows the victim's hand.
Evidence 8
Name: The Fourth Book
Description: A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. The back cover is badly burnt. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining the burnt corner on the back before it is specifically pointed out in court.) A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' that was in the victim's hand when Mrs Beate first ran over to see what had happened.
Evidence 9
Name: Warrant Card
Description: A small folding wallet that identifies London bobbies and contains the rules of conduct to which they must adhere.
Evidence 10
Name: Anniversary Bouquet
Description: A present for Patricia Beate from her husband, Roly. The shock of seeing the stabbed victim caused Mrs Beate to drop the rose where she stood.
Evidence 11
Name: Pipe
Description: Mr Garrideb's pipe. Apparently it fell to the floor during a domestic dispute he had with his wife and broke.
Evidence 12
Name: Fragment of Metal
Description: This small piece of metal looks like it might be the tip of a knife blade. It was stuck inside the bowl of Mr Garrideb's pipe.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: As I said, it was five o'clock in the afternoon when the incident occurred. And there was an unusually light fog.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 1
Testimony: Visibility was reasonably good, and there was no one else about but the victim and the accused.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 2
Testimony: Out of the blue, the victim was stabbed from behind and subsequently collapsed on the pavement.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 3
Testimony: The accused ran off, scatterin' his belongings all over the floor.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 4
Testimony: Those bein' a number of old books he'd just bought. He was on his way home from a bookshop, it seems.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 5
Testimony: He was on his way home from Bourbon Books, a secondhand bookshop he apparently patronises.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 6
Testimony: It was just a matter of workin' out who the books belonged to, and we found the bloke to arrest him.
Person: Gregson

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
Okay, let's tackle this problem. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. Let me go through them step by step.

First, let's look at the testimonies. All the testimonies are from Gregson (Testimony 0 to 6). He mentions that the incident happened at 5 PM with light fog, good visibility, only the victim and accused present. The accused (Soseki Natsume) ran off, scattering belongings including old books he just bought from Bourbon Books. The police used the books to find and arrest him.

Now, looking at the evidence. Let's check each one to see if there's a contradiction with any of Gregson's statements. 

Evidence 3 is a receipt from a secondhand bookshop found in Natsume's room. Gregson's Testimony 5 says Natsume was coming from Bourbon Books, which matches the receipt. So that's consistent.

Evidence 8 is "The Fourth Book" found in the victim's hand, titled 'The Lion's Pride'. The back cover is burnt. Testimony 6 says they worked out who the books belonged to and arrested him. But according to Testimony 3 and 4, Natsume dropped his books when he ran. However, if the victim was holding a book, that book wouldn't be among the ones Natsume dropped. So the presence of the book in the victim's hand contradicts the testimony that all the books scattered were Natsume's. The receipt (Evidence 3) lists the books Natsume bought, but if 'The Lion's Pride' wasn't among them, then the book in the victim's hand isn't his. This would mean Gregson's claim that they identified him via the books is flawed because one book wasn't his, contradicting Testimony 6.

Another angle: Evidence 8's book was in the victim's hand when Mrs. Beate arrived. If the victim had it, then it wasn't part of the scattered books from Natsume. Therefore, the police might have incorrectly linked all books to Natsume, but this one wasn't his. The receipt would show which books he bought, and if 'The Lion's Pride' isn't on the receipt, that's a contradiction. But I need to check Evidence 3's description. Evidence 3 is a receipt for "some books" from the secondhand shop. If The Lion's Pride isn't listed there, then that's a contradiction. But the receipt's description doesn't specify which books, so maybe the fact that the book was burnt (possibly indicating it's from another source) contradicts the idea that all books were Natsume's. So Testimony 6 says they found the owner via the books, but if one book wasn't his, then that's a contradiction. Therefore, Evidence 8 (The Fourth Book) contradicts Testimony 6 because the book in the victim's hand isn't Natsume's, making the arrest based on incorrect evidence.

{"evidence": 8, "testimony": 6}

response:

First, looking at Testimony 4 by Patricia: She claims that the defendant, Soseki Natsume, was the one they saw at the scene. But maybe there's evidence that contradicts this. Let's check the evidences.

Evidence 3 is a receipt from a secondhand bookshop found in Natsume's room. If he bought books, maybe that's related. Then Testimony 5 says Patricia can name the four books he dropped. However, Evidence 8 is a book called 'The Lion's Pride' found in the victim's hand. Wait, the receipt in Evidence 3 might list the books he bought. If the receipt shows four books, but the victim has a fifth book (The Lion's Pride), that would contradict Patricia's Testimony 5, which says he dropped four books. But the receipt is for "some books" but doesn't specify the number. Hmm. Alternatively, maybe the fourth book is part of the ones he bought. Wait, the receipt is from before the incident. If the defendant's books were four, but the victim's book is a fifth one, then Patricia's Testimony 5 (naming four books he dropped) would conflict because the fifth book at the scene wasn't his. But how does the evidence show that? The receipt (Evidence 3) is for books purchased by Natsume. If the receipt lists specific titles, but The Lion's Pride isn't among them, then the presence of that book at the scene would contradict Patricia's assertion that the books he dropped are the four from the receipt. Wait, but the receipt's description just says "some books", so maybe without specific titles, it's hard to link. Alternatively, perhaps the number of books is the issue. If Patricia says he dropped four books (Testimony 5), but the crime scene has one book in the victim's hand (Evidence 8), plus maybe others? But the evidence doesn't mention other books. Wait, in the evidence list, Evidence 8 is the only book mentioned. So if Patricia claims he dropped four books, but only one is found at the scene, that's a contradiction. However, maybe the receipt (Evidence 3) shows that Natsume bought four books, and the victim's book is one of them. So if the victim's book is part of the four, then there's no contradiction. Alternatively, if the receipt is for four books, but the victim has a fifth, then Patricia's testimony about the four books would be wrong. But the problem is that the receipt's description doesn't state the number of books. Wait, looking back: Evidence 3 is "some books that he had purchased from a secondhand bookshop before the incident occurred." So "some" could be any number. Testimony 5 says Patricia can name the four books he dropped. So if she's claiming he dropped four, but the receipt shows he bought, say, four, then that's consistent. But Evidence 8 is a fifth book, which wasn't among those he bought. Wait, but maybe The Lion's Pride is one of the four. However, without the receipt's specific contents, perhaps this is not directly conflicting. Let's consider another angle. Evidence 8 states that the book was in the victim's hand when Mrs. Beate first ran over. But Patricia's Testimony 2 says that the other person (the defendant) scattered something before running off. However, if the book in the victim's hand (Evidence 8) isn't one of those four, then her testimony would be wrong. But how do we know? The problem is that the receipt's description doesn't specify the titles. Unless the receipt in Evidence 3 lists four books, and the book in Evidence 8 is a fifth one. But without explicit titles, maybe that's hard. Alternatively, maybe the receipt's date and time could conflict with the incident's timing. Wait, Evidence 8's updated description mentions that the back cover is badly burnt, which can be noticed by examining it. But the question is which specific evidence and testimony contradict each other. So perhaps the contradiction is between Patricia's Testimony 4 (saw Natsume) and Evidence 12 (fragment from Garrideb's pipe). But how does Evidence 12 directly contradict her testimony? Maybe the knife used was broken, and the fragment links to Garrideb, suggesting the real culprit is connected to him, thus contradicting Patricia's identification of Natsume. But that's a bit indirect. Alternatively, the pipe (Evidence 11) broke during a domestic dispute. If the fragment (Evidence 12) is from the knife used in the crime, then the knife was broken during the dispute, meaning the attacker was at the Garrideb residence, not Natsume. Therefore, the presence of the book in the victim's hand contradicts Testimony 2, which says the defendant scattered things. But that's a possible angle. Alternatively, Testimony 2 says the other person (defendant) scattered something, but the book was in the victim's hand, implying the victim had it before being attacked, not scattered by the defendant. So the contradiction could be between Testimony 2 (scattered by defendant) and Evidence 8 (victim holding it). But is that a solid contradiction? Therefore, Evidence 8 (book in victim's hand) contradicts Testimony 2 (defendant scattered items). But Testimony 2 is from Patricia. Let me check the exact wording of Testimony 2: "All of a sudden, one of them just collapsed on the floor. Then the other scattered something before running off!" So after one person (victim) collapsed, the other (defendant) scattered something. But the book was in the victim's hand when Mrs. Beate first ran over (Evidence 8's description). So if the defendant scattered items after the victim collapsed, but the book was in the victim's hand, then the book couldn't have been scattered by the defendant. Therefore, the book must have been in the victim's possession before collapsing, meaning the defendant didn't scatter it. Hence, Evidence 8 contradicts Testimony 2. So the pair would be Evidence 8 and Testimony 2. Let's check the JSON: {"evidence": 8, "testimony": 2}. Is that correct? Yes. The testimony says the defendant scattered something, but the evidence shows the book was in the victim's hand, not scattered. Therefore, contradiction.

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Summarized Context:

Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 2
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 3
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A scholar sent to Britain by the Japanese government to further his study of English. He's the defendant accused of attempted murder.
Character 4
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 5
Name: Maid → Joan Garrideb
Description: A maid who works at the Garrideb household. Her main duty appears to be standing at Mr Garrideb's side pouring tea.
Character 6
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 7
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous 'great detective'. Not a person except me, apparently.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey, though concrete details of the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Olive Green
Description: The victim of this case, who was found with a knife in her back. Luckily, the wound didn't prove fatal, but the woman remains unconscious in her hospital bed.
Character 10
Name: Roly Beate
Description: A devoted London bobby who witnessed the incident whilst walking down the street with his wife of a year, Patricia.
Character 11
Name: Patricia Beate
Description: The wife of Constable Roly Beate who is a witness to the incident. She's relatively recently married, and fiercely proud of her policeman husband.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Local Map
Description: A street map of the local area showing where the victim was found. A street map of the local area showing locations that are relevant to the case.
Evidence 2
Name: Iris's Postcard
Description: A card for Inspector Gregson with a message on the back from Iris.
Evidence 3
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt discovered in Mr Natsume's room for some books that he had purchased from a secondhand bookshop before the incident occurred.
Evidence 4
Name: Case File
Description: A file containing an overview of the case and details about the victim. She was found with a knife in her back and is currently in hospital, yet to regain consciousness. The pavement where the victim was found lies just outside Constable Beate's beat, the border of which runs down the middle of Briar Road.
Evidence 5
Name: Jackknife
Description: A large but commonplace folding knife. It was found lodged in the victim's back.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident occurred. A large knife can be seen thrust into the victim's back.
Evidence 7
Name: Crime Scene Photograph #2
Description: A second photograph of the scene taken by a policeman just after the incident. It specifically shows the victim's hand.
Evidence 8
Name: The Fourth Book
Description: A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' discovered in the victim's hand at the scene. The back cover is badly burnt. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining the burnt corner on the back before it is specifically pointed out in court.) A book entitled 'The Lion's Pride' that was in the victim's hand when Mrs Beate first ran over to see what had happened.
Evidence 9
Name: Warrant Card
Description: A small folding wallet that identifies London bobbies and contains the rules of conduct to which they must adhere.
Evidence 10
Name: Anniversary Bouquet
Description: A present for Patricia Beate from her husband, Roly. The shock of seeing the stabbed victim caused Mrs Beate to drop the rose where she stood.
Evidence 11
Name: Pipe
Description: Mr Garrideb's pipe. Apparently it fell to the floor during a domestic dispute he had with his wife and broke.
Evidence 12
Name: Fragment of Metal
Description: This small piece of metal looks like it might be the tip of a knife blade. It was stuck inside the bowl of Mr Garrideb's pipe.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Yes, on the day you're referring to, the wife and I did have a bit of a skirmish. Can't recall the reason now.
Person: Garrideb
Testimony 1
Testimony: Knocked a candlestick over and set fire to the carpet! Soon had it out, though, and got the window open.
Person: Garrideb
Testimony 2
Testimony: Meanwhile...I was picking up whatever I could find to throw at him.
Person: Joan
Testimony 3
Testimony: Plenty of knives around our place. Can't say I'd notice if one or two went missing, I'm afraid.
Person: Garrideb
Testimony 4
Testimony: If that bally thing in the victim's back really was one of ours, you'll have a job proving it, I think.
Person: Garrideb

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
